unnormalised: Healthcare data is increasingly reliant on numerical information. From patient demographics to vital signs and diagnostic test results, numbers play a crucial role in diagnosis, treatment, and overall patient care. Accurately interpreting and managing this numerical data is paramount for healthcare professionals and researchers alike. This article aims to provide an educational overview of various types of numerical data commonly found in healthcare and medical records, highlighting their significance and potential pitfalls.

unnormalised: One of the most basic forms of numerical data involves patient demographics. Age, often recorded as a whole number (e.g., 62), is a key factor influencing treatment decisions. Body Mass Index (BMI), calculated using weight and height measurements (e.g., weight in kg / (height in meters)^2), provides a valuable indicator of overall health status, often presented to 2 decimal places (e.g., 27.54). Both of these figures are usually recorded upon admission or during initial consultations.
normalised: One of the most basic forms of numerical data involves patient demographics. Age, often recorded as a whole number (e.g., sixty two), is a key factor influencing treatment decisions. Body Mass Index (B-M-I), calculated using weight and height measurements (e.g., weight in kilogram divided by height in meters squared), provides a valuable indicator of overall health status, often presented to two decimal places (e.g., twenty seven point five four). Both of these figures are usually recorded upon admission or during initial consultations.

unnormalised: Vital signs constitute another essential category of numerical data. Blood pressure, expressed as systolic/diastolic (e.g., 120/80 mmHg), indicates cardiovascular health. Heart rate, measured in beats per minute (bpm), provides insights into cardiac function (e.g., 72 bpm). Body temperature, typically recorded in degrees Celsius or Fahrenheit (e.g., 37°C or 98.6°F), is a critical indicator of infection or inflammation. Respiratory rate, usually documented as breaths per minute (e.g., 16 breaths/min), assists in assessing pulmonary health. Variations in these numbers can alert the medical team, such as a drop in BP below 90/60 or a sudden spike in temperature to 102°F.
normalised: Vital signs constitute another essential category of numerical data. Blood pressure, expressed as systolic divided by diastolic (e.g., one hundred and twenty divided by eighty millimeter of mercury), indicates cardiovascular health. Heart rate, measured in beats per minute (B-P-M), provides insights into cardiac function (e.g., seventy two B-P-M). Body temperature, typically recorded in degrees Celsius or Fahrenheit (e.g., thirty seven degree celsius or ninety eight point six degree fahrenheit), is a critical indicator of infection or inflammation. Respiratory rate, usually documented as breaths per minute (e.g., sixteen breaths per minute), assists in assessing pulmonary health. Variations in these numbers can alert the medical team, such as a drop in B-P below ninety divided by sixty or a sudden spike in temperature to one hundred and two degree fahrenheit.

unnormalised: Diagnostic test results generate a wealth of numerical data. Blood glucose levels, measured in mg/dL (e.g., 95 mg/dL), are vital for managing diabetes. Cholesterol levels, including total cholesterol, HDL, and LDL, also measured in mg/dL (e.g., Total Cholesterol: 200 mg/dL), assess cardiovascular risk. Complete blood count (CBC) reports include numerous parameters such as hemoglobin (Hb) levels in g/dL (e.g., Hb: 14.5 g/dL), white blood cell (WBC) count in cells/µL (e.g., WBC: 7000 cells/µL), and platelet count in cells/µL (e.g., Platelets: 250000 cells/µL). Radiology reports often include measurements of tumor size in cm (e.g., Tumor size: 3.5 cm).
normalised: Diagnostic test results generate a wealth of numerical data. Blood glucose levels, measured in milligram per deciliter (e.g., ninety five milligram per deciliter), are vital for managing diabetes. Cholesterol levels, including total cholesterol, H-D-L, and L-D-L, also measured in milligram per deciliter (e.g., Total Cholesterol: two hundred milligram per deciliter), assess cardiovascular risk. Complete blood count (C-B-C) reports include numerous parameters such as hemoglobin (H-B) levels in gram per deciliter (e.g., H-B: fourteen point five gram per deciliter), white blood cell (W-B-C) count in cells per microliter (e.g., W-B-C: seven thousand cells per microliter), and platelet count in cells per microliter (e.g., Platelets: two hundred and fifty thousand cells per microliter). Radiology reports often include measurements of tumor size in centimeter (e.g., Tumor size: three point five centimeter).

unnormalised: Medication dosages and administration details involve precise numerical data. Dosages are typically expressed in milligrams (mg) or micrograms (mcg) (e.g., Amoxicillin 500mg, Thyroxine 25mcg). Frequency of administration is also numerically quantified (e.g., twice daily or TDS, every 8 hours or Q8H). Intravenous (IV) fluid infusion rates are measured in milliliters per hour (mL/hr) (e.g., IV fluids at 100 mL/hr). Careful attention to these numbers is essential to prevent medication errors.

Intravenous (I-V) fluid infusion rates are measured in milliliters per hour (mL/hr) (e.g., I-V fluids at one hundred milliliter per hour). unnormalised: Medical billing and coding processes also heavily rely on numerical data. Procedure codes (e.g., ICD-10 codes) are used for reimbursement purposes. Costs of procedures, medications, and hospital stays are quantified in Rupees (Rs.) (e.g., Consultation fee: Rs. 500, Hospital stay per day: Rs. 5000). Insurance claim amounts are also represented numerically. These numbers are key to monitoring expenses, ensuring fair reimbursements and compliance.

unnormalised: Analyzing trends in numerical healthcare data can provide valuable insights for improving patient outcomes and resource allocation. Epidemiological studies rely on statistical analysis of numerical data to identify risk factors and disease patterns. Clinical trials use numerical data to evaluate the effectiveness of new treatments. Hospital administrators utilize numerical data to track key performance indicators (KPIs) such as patient readmission rates, infection rates, and length of stay in days (e.g., Average length of stay: 4.2 days).
